articles.title: Winning numbers announced for estimated $1.4 billion Powerball jackpot - CBS News
articles.description: The estimated Powerball jackpot for Saturday night's drawing soared to an estimated $1.7 billion after no tickets came up winners of Wednesday's $1.4 grand prize.

articles.title: Amazon to end Prime program allowing shared free shipping - NewsNation
articles.description: Starting Oct. 1, Prime membership holders will no longer be able to share free shipping benefits with people who don’t share their address.

articles.title: Asian Stocks to Rise as Weak US Jobs Fuel Fed Bets: Markets Wrap - Bloomberg
articles.description: Asian equities slowed their advance as a selloff in Chinese stocks intensified, eroding earlier optimism about Federal Reserve policy easing after weak US job openings data.

articles.title: ConocoPhillips says it will cut workforce by 20-25%, shares fall - CNBC
articles.description: Shares of the third-largest U.S. oil producer declined 4.5% to $94.55, outpacing a 2.6% drop in the broader S&P 500 Energy Index.

articles.title: Jim VandeHei: Getting a grip on America's paralyzing hope crisis - Axios
articles.description: We have a crisis far bigger than nasty politics, surging screen time or economic angst.

articles.title: American Eagle's shares soar as Sydney Sweeney boosts sales - BBC
articles.description: The US actress was part of the company's controversial "Great Jeans" campaign which drew a backlash.

articles.description: Wall Street is coming off a mixed session.

articles.description: Tough enforcement continues even as tech bosses court the president

articles.title: News network Newsmax files antitrust suit vs. Fox News - Politico
articles.description: “Fox’s behavior represents a textbook abuse of monopoly power,” Newsmax lawyer Michael J. Guzman said.

articles.title: Spirit Airlines to end service to 11 cities amid bankruptcy - The Points Guy
articles.description: Spirit Airlines will cut 11 cities from its route map as part of its latest Chapter 11 bankruptcy restruturing.

articles.title: Trump Inc.’s $5.4 Billion Digital Coin Hit by Turbulence - Bloomberg
articles.description: Trump Inc.’s much-trumpeted crypto foray — the WLFI token — launched Monday with ambitions of serving as the backbone of a new digital ecosystem. Within hours, it was mired in the turbulence and instability that has long been the hallmarks of crypto trading.

articles.title: Pentagon cuts back F-35 upgrades to slow schedule slips: Auditors - Defense News
articles.description: The F-35's Block 4 upgrades are being trimmed back so the program can focus on what it can deliver in 2031.

articles.title: Figma warns of upcoming share unlock as stock sinks post-earnings - Yahoo Finance

articles.title: Can you get a COVID shot? Here’s your fall vaccine guide - PBS
articles.description: Many people across the United States are wondering if they will be able to get vaccinated at all, particularly against COVID, after changes to vaccine guidance by the Trump administration.

articles.title: Bearish Treasuries Bets Grow as Traders Brace for Key Jobs Data - Bloomberg.com
articles.description: Bearish bets are proliferating in US Treasuries and raising the stakes around Friday’s employment report, which may cement views on how aggressively the Federal Reserve will cut interest rates at its September meeting.

articles.title: Trump family's American Bitcoin makes stock market debut - NBC News
articles.description: Shares in the Trump family’s latest cryptocurrency made its stock market debut Wednesday, triggering more ethical concerns as the Trumps look to cash in on crypto as the president’s administration weakens regulations for the nascent industry

articles.title: Texas lawmakers working on last-minute deal to tighten restrictions on THC products - The Texas Tribune
articles.description: Legislators couldn’t reach a last-minute deal to tighten regulations on consumable hemp products.

articles.title: Rising Tariff Costs Squeeze Consumers, as Federal Reserve Report Highlights Economic Strain - Investopedia
articles.description: The main pillars of the economy—employment and consumer spending—are both straining under the weight of tariffs, according to a report from the Federal Reserve.
